data.title: Behold the new films for 2004
authors: CHRISTOPHER LLOYD Staff , The Star Banner

data.text:
Even as we're sorting out the best and brightest in cinema from 2003, there's a whole new year waiting for us.

In 2004 we'll get computer-generated cats ("Garfield") and dogs ("Scooby Doo 2"), and movies where stars like Tom Cruise ("Collateral") and Robert Redford ("The Clearing") are kidnapped. A science fiction classic will finally be translated to the big screen when Will Smith stars in "I, Robot" based on Isaac Asimov's novel.

Oh, and we're expecting another visit from a not-so-boyish-anymore wizard named Potter.

Romance movies will see some new twists in the new year, with couples separated by disjointed realities and surreal set-ups.

Josh Hartnett and Ashton Kutcher travel through time and the mind's inner landscape in, respectively, "Wicker Park" and "The Butterfly Effect." Adam Sandler woos a girl who can't remember him in "50 First Dates." And Jim Carrey has his memories of lousy romance erased in "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind."

The past year was a great one for animation, and 2004 is shaping up nicely, too, with "Shrek 2," the bovine Disney musical "Home on the Range" and the latest computer-animated effort from Pixar, "The Incredibles."

Look for more sequels ("Barbershop 2," "Spider-Man 2"), comic book translations ("Catwoman," "The Punisher"), remakes ("The Stepford Wives," "Walking Tall") and a rebirth of the sandal-and-toga epic (Brad Pitt in "Troy," Colin Farrell in "Alexander").

Here's a very early look at what's heading down the pike. Please note, all release dates are subject to change.

JANUARY

Chasing Liberty: Jan. 9 - Believe it or not, for a while there we were going to have two movies, both titled "First Daughter," about the dating troubles of the daughter of the President. And they were even going to be released on the same day! But the studios blinked, so the version starring Mandy Moore changed its title to "Chasing Liberty." "First Daughter," starring Katie Holmes, will be released later in 2004.

Along Came Polly: Jan. 16 - Ben Stiller plays a seriously uptight guy who falls for free spirit Jennifer Aniston in this romantic comedy from the "Meet the Parents" crew. Co-starring Alec Baldwin, Debra Messing, Philip Seymour Hoffman and Hank Azaria.

The Butterfly Effect: Jan. 23 - Can Gen-Y prankster Ashton Kutcher ("Dude, Where's My Car") make it in a serious role? He stars in this psychological thriller about a man trying to solve the mystery of his frequent blackouts.

The Big Bounce: Jan. 30 - This ensemble caper comedy set in Hawaii is about an inept small-time thief who's seduced by a naughty girl into pulling a big job. It stars Owen Wilson, Morgan Freeman, Sara Foster, Gary Sinise and Charlie Sheen.

FEBRUARY

Barbershop 2: Back in Business: Feb. 6 - The gang from the hit comedy is back for another cut, with Ice Cube, Sean Patrick Thomas, Queen Latifah, Eve and Cedric the Entertainer.

Against the Ropes: Feb. 6 - Meg Ryan's comeback attempt fizzled with the psycho-sexual thriller "In the Cut," and things aren't looking good for this biopic about a real-life female boxing manager, which has seen its release date delayed several times. Omar Epps, Charles S. Dutton co-star.

Miracle: Feb. 6 - The true story of the Miracle on Ice - the U.S. upset of the Soviet team at the 1980 Olympics that many consider the single greatest moment in sports - is told starring Kurt Russell as coach Herb Brooks, who molds a ragtag group of players into champions.

Welcome to Mooseport: Feb. 6 - Talk about an inspired concept: Ray Romano plays a plumber who's trying to court a girl and run for mayor of his small town - and his opponent in both endeavors is none other than the lame-duck U.S. President (Gene Hackman).

50 First Dates: Feb. 13 - The latest Adam Sandler comedy reunites him with his "Wedding Singer" co-star Drew Barrymore. They're in love, but she has short-term memory loss a la "Memento," so she forgets he's her boyfriend, and he must woo her again and again.

Kill Bill: Volume II: Feb. 20 - The Bride (Uma Thurman) continues her quest for revenge against the assassination squad that tried to kill her, led by the enigmatic Bill (David Carradine). Think it'll be bloody? Written and directed by Quentin Tarantino.

The Passion of Christ: Feb. 25 - Mel Gibson's controversial drama about the last hours of Jesus has been both hailed for its realistic depiction of his tortures and attacked as anti-Semitic. John Caviezel stars.

MARCH

Hidalgo: March 5 - Viggo Mortensen of the "Lord of the Rings" movies stars in this pet project about an epic horse race in the Arab desert, with a has-been cowboy and his aging mustang competing against the finest horses and riders in the world.

Starsky & Hutch: March 6 - The '70s TV stars get a big screen comedy treatment starring Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson. Co-starring Vince Vaughn, Carmen Electra, and Snoop Dogg as Huggy Bear.

Spartan: March 12 - The latest from writer/director David Mamet stars Val Kilmer and Derek Luke as supercops looking for a kidnapped girl the rest of the world believes is already dead.

Agent Cody Banks 2: Destination London: March 12 - The pint-sized James Bond battles bad guys in England. Starring Frankie Muniz and Anthony Anderson.

Taking Lives: March 19 - Angelina Jolie stars in this thriller as an intuitive investigator on the trail of a "lifejacker" - someone who murders people and then assumes their identity. Co-starring Kiefer Sutherland and Olivier Martinez.

Jersey Girl: March 19 - Are you ready for Bennifer Part Deaux? Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lopez star in this comedy about a callow dude who suddenly becomes a family man. Written and directed by Kevin Smith ("Chasing Amy").

Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind: March 19 - Has the title of an art-house flick, but is actually a comedy/drama starring Jim Carrey and Kate Winslet as a couple trying to save their failing relationship by using technology to remove the bad memories. Things go awry.

The Ladykillers: March 26 - Filmmaking siblings Joel and Ethan Coen ("Intolerable Cruelty," "Fargo") team up with Tom Hanks in a heist comedy about a group of incompetent thieves whose plans for a big job are spoiled by the little old lady upstairs.

Scooby Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed: March 26 - CGI Scooby is back. He and the gang battle a villain who's invented a machine that recreates all their old enemies.

APRIL

Hellboy: April 2 - An "X-Men"-ish actioner where the super-powered heroes are more obviously freakish, led by the title character (Ron Perlman), a demon summoned by the Nazis who turned to good. Starring Selma Blair and Doug Jones.

Home on the Range: April 2 - The cows take center stage in this animated musical from Disney. They're trying to save their farm by finding a legendary yodeler. Featuring the voices of Judi Dench, Steve Buscemi, Cuba Gooding Jr., Trisha Yearwood, Roseanne Barr and Sarah Jessica Parker.

The Whole Ten Yards: April 9 - Bruce Willis, Matthew Perry and Amanda Peet return in the sequel to the comedy about assassins living in suburbia.

Walking Tall: April 9 - The Rock stars as a retired soldier who returns to clean up his hometown of drugs and crime. Co-starring Johnny Knoxville.

The Alamo: April 9 - This supposedly more historically accurate take on the 1836 battle was pushed back from the holiday season - never a good sign. Starring Dennis Quaid and Billy Bob Thornton.

The Punisher: April 16 - Another comic book adaptation, this one about a mirthless gun-toting vigilante (Thomas Jane) who 86s his enemies. Starring John Travolta as the heavy.

Saved!: April 23 - A drama set at a Christian high school pits good girl Mandy Moore against her best friend (Jena Malone), who has become pregnant.

Man on Fire: April 23 - Denzel Washington stars in this action/drama about a burnt-out soldier of fortune who agrees to guard a young girl (Dakota Fanning), and becomes attached to her. Christopher Walken co-stars.

Johnson Family Vacation: April - A sort of African-American version of "National Lampoon's Vacation" starring Cedric the Entertainer, Vanessa Williams and Bow Wow as a family that gets lost when their car's navigation computer goes kerflooey.

MAY

Van Helsing: May 7 - Hugh Jackman gets his own summer franchise as the legendary vampire hunter. Co-starring Kate Beckinsale, with Richard Roxburgh as Dracula.

Mr. 3000: May 14 - This baseball flick had numerous stars attached at various points, including John Travolta and Samuel L. Jackson. Bernie Mac ended up in the title role as a retired hall-of-famer who returns to the game at age 47 to try and reach 3,000 hits.

Shrek 2: May 21 - The not-so-jolly green goliath is back and facing an even more daunting challenge than dragons or evil kings: meeting his wife's parents! Featuring the voices of Mike Myers, Cameron Diaz, Eddie Murphy and John Cleese.

Troy: May 21 - Director Wolfgang Petersen ("The Perfect Storm") takes on the great tale by Homer (that's the "Illiad" guy, not the "D'oh!" guy) of war and loss. Brad Pitt plays Achilles, the invincible - almost - hero. With Eric Bana, Orlando Bloom, Peter O'Toole and Julie Christie. With Diane Kruger as the face that launched a thousand media blitzes.

Soul Plane: May 28 - A hip-hop comedy take-off on "Airplane!" starring Snoop Dogg, Method Man, Missi Pyle, D.L. Hughley, Mo'Nique and more.

13 Going on 30: May 28 - Jennifer Garner stars in another body-switcheroo comedy as an unpopular 13-year-old who returns in the body of a hot 30-year-old woman. Co-starring Mark Ruffalo.

The Day After Tomorrow: May 28 - A special-effects disaster flick about global warming. Climatologist Dennis Quaid must save his son (Jake Gyllenhaal) in New York, which is being overtaken by a new Ice Age.

JUNE

Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban: June 4 - More wizardly adventures as Harry, Hermione and Ron contend with escaped mad sorcerer Sirius Black (Gary Oldman). Michael Gambon takes over for the late Richard Harris as Headmaster Dumbledore.

The Stepford Wives: June 11 - Nicole Kidman headlines this remake of the 1970s classic about an entire town of misogynist men who have replaced their wives with perfect robots. Directed by Frank Oz, this is a campier version than the original. Co-starring Bette Midler, Glenn Close, Matthew Broderick, Christopher Walken and Faith Hill.

Garfield: June 18 - A comedy based on the popular (who knows why?) comic strip about the cat who loves lasagna and hates Mondays. With a CGI Garfield voiced by Bill Murray.

The Terminal: June 18 - Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks team up for a third time in this heartwarming drama about an immigrant trapped in a New York terminal because his tiny home country has ceased to exist. Co-starring Catherine Zeta-Jones as the flight attendant he falls in love with.

JULY

De-Lovely: July 2 - Kevin Kline stars in this biopic of composer Cole Porter. Co-starring Ashley Judd, with a host of appearances by musical stars including Natalie Cole, Elvis Costello, Sheryl Crow and Alanis Morissette.

Spider-Man II: July 2 - Your friendly neighborhood web-head is back, and he's up against the many-tentacled Dr. Octopus (Alfred Molina). Tobey Maguire, Kirsten Dunst star.

King Arthur: July 7 - This umpteenth take on Camelot is supposed to be a grimmer, demystified look at the legend. With Clive Owen as King Arthur and Keira Knightly as Guinevere.

Anchorman: July 9 - Comedy with Will Ferrell playing a pompous 1970s TV anchorman with really bad taste in clothes who's pitted against a female journalist who actually has talent.

I, Robot: July 16 - The Isaac Asimov science fiction classic finally comes to life starring Will Smith as a detective investigating a crime he believes was perpetrated by a robot, which have become household items in the year 2035.

Catwoman: July 30 - The Batman franchise gets its first spin-off with Halle Berry playing the growly girl in tights seeking revenge on her father's killer. Sharon Stone co-stars.

The Village: July 30 - Writer/director M. Night Shyamalan's newest mystery/thriller is about a group of people living in an isolated village with an unknown danger lurking in the outskirts. Starring Joaquin Phoenix, Sigourney Weaver, Adrien Brody and William Hurt.

AUGUST

Alien vs. Predator: Aug. 6 - The popular movies that became popular sequels that became a popular video game featuring the boogums from each franchise going head-to-head now becomes . . . a movie.

Code 46: Aug. 6 - Tim Robbins stars in this futuristic drama about a woman (Samantha Morton) who is an outcast in a heavily regulated society.

Princess Diaries 2: Royal Engagement: Aug. 11 - Anne Hathaway charmed her way through the original about a regular American kid who finds out she's the princess of a small country. In the sequel, she and her grandmother the queen (Julie Andrews), take a European road trip.

Blade: Trinity: Aug. 13 - Wesley Snipes is back for a third go-round as the grim half-vampire hero. In this (supposed) finale to the series, Blade takes on Dracula himself.

Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow: Summer - Gwyneth Paltrow enters the summer blockbuster race in this thriller set in 1939 about a reporter who discovers the world's greatest scientists are disappearing. With Jude Law in the title role and co-starring Angelina Jolie.

SEPTEMBER

Resident Evil: Apocalypse: Sept. 24 - Milla Jovovich returns as the zombie-fighting heroine in this sequel to last summer's surprise hit based on a video game.

Wimbledon: Sept. 24 - Can this movie do for tennis what "Seabiscuit" did for horse racing? Paul Bettany plays a down-and-out player who tries a comeback with the help of "bad girl of tennis" Kirsten Dunst.

OCTOBER

Ladder 99: Oct. 8 - This drama stars Joaquin Phoenix as a firefighter trapped inside a burning building who reflects on his life, and John Travolta as the heroic fire chief trying to rescue him.

Collateral: October - This Tom Cruise vehicle - literally - has him driving a cab. One night, a contract killer forces him to drive him around from hit to hit, and Cruise struggles to save the lives of the targets before becoming a victim himself.

NOVEMBER

The Incredibles: Nov. 5 - The newest computer animation film from Pixar ("Finding Nemo") features a family of super-heroes trying to live the quiet life, but who are called back into action to save the world. Featuring the voices of Craig T. Nelson, Holly Hunter, Samuel L. Jackson and Jason Lee.

Alexander: Nov. 5 - One of two epics about Alexander the Great. This one stars Colin Farrell and was written and directed by Oliver Stone. Another Alexander film starring Leonardo DiCaprio comes out in 2005. Get this: Angelina Jolie, who's all of 11 months older than Farrell, plays his mother.

Be Cool: November - This sequel to "Get Shorty" stars John Travolta as a mobster who, having conquered the film industry, muscles in on the music biz. Uma Thurman, Danny DeVito and The Rock co-star.

J.M. Barrie's Neverland: November - A new take on the "Peter Pan" myth, this time centering on the man who was inspired by parentless children to write the original tale, played by Johnny Depp. Kate Winslet, Julie Christie, Dustin Hoffman co-star.

Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason: November - More romantic misadventures for the Brit lit chick (Ren√©e Zellweger) who wears infamously large bloomers. Hugh Grant, Colin Firth reprise their roles.

DECEMBER

Ocean's Twelve: Dec. 12 - Remember when Steven Soderbergh made little auteur films? He's back on the Hollywood bandwagon in this heist sequel starring George Clooney, Brad Pitt, Julia Roberts, Bernie Mac and Matt Damon.

The Aviator: Dec. 17 - Martin Scorsese's ambitious biopic of Howard Hughes stars Leonardo DiCaprio as the visionary/disturbed industrialist. Cate Blanchett plays Katherine Hepburn and singer Gwen Stefani plays Jean Harlow.

FALL

Mr. and Mrs. Smith: Fall - Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie play married assassins who have been hired to kill each other.

Beauty Shop: Fall - Queen Latifah stars in a spin-off to "Barbershop," which features women sitting around dishing instead of the boys.

Wicker Park: Fall - A romantic thriller about a man searching for the woman he loved, who vanished without a trace. Starring Josh Hartnett.

I (heart) Huckabee's: Fall - A stellar cast including Dustin Hoffman, Isabelle Huppert, Jude Law, Jason Schwartzman, Lily Tomlin, Mark Wahlberg and Naomi Watts in a very existential comedy about a young man investigating bizarre coincidences connected to Huckabee's, a chain of Wal-Martish superstores.

The Clearing: Fall - This kidnapping drama stars Robert Redford and Helen Mirren as a perfect couple approaching their golden years whose bliss is shattered when the husband is held for ransom by Willem Dafoe.

Christopher Lloyd is entertainment editor at the Star-Banner. Contact him at 867-4154 or christopher.lloyd@starbanner.com.
